medium: Pen and brown ink with red chalk (for seated figure) on light tan laid paper
inscribed:
Inscribed recto, lower left, in brown ink: 3.60,
18; inscribed verso, upper right, in brown ink:
Sig Vicentio Odaldi / Pistolese / Marco Argimoni;
center and lower right, three times in brown ink:
Anda Commodi; verso, center, in brown ink: Ab, . . .
sigr mio

texts.textentryhtml: These figure studies were made in preparation for frescoes of the Last Judgment in the Palazzo Quirinale in Rome, an unfinished commission on which Commodi worked relentlessly from 1609 to 1622. The large central figure reveals both Commodi’s frequent use of life models and his emulation of Michelangelo. The surrounding sprightly, acrobatic figures— together with the intricate knot designs and calligraphic inscriptions (including iterations of Commodi’s signature) on the verso—illustrate not only the workings of an inventive mind but also the exploratory ways in which the artist used both sides of the paper.

Peter Lely; J. Richardson Sr; Ferruccio Asta; Delius Giese, New York;

Handwritten note: “Attribution changed on recommendation of P. Pouncey, 1965.”;

Note by F. Delius: “Dr. Parker, Director of the Ashmolean Museum at Oxford, attributed this drawing to the master, comparing it with similar drawings at Windsor Castle.”;

Penciled note on back of mount: “Francesco da Simone (nach anderer Ansicht frühe Michelangelo). Feder und Rötel, studienblatt.  22 x 28,3 cm. Coll. Stroganoff, Firenze, Josua Reynolds, Peter Lely.”;

From Lugt, “Les Marques de collections…”: #550 for Stroganoff stamp; #2092 for Lely. Cf. p. 388 under Lely entry mentioning that alphabetical listings were given the drawings in Lely’s estate; AF apparently one of these. Reynolds’ Stamp is different from the stamp on the lower left corner of the Princeton drawings. (See reference Bib. 4661);

From Gibbons, “Catalogue of Italian drawings…”: as circle of Ludovico Cardi da Cigoli. (See reference Bib. 4362);

From Cappel, “Leonarde, tagliente…”: mentioned on p. 91 and p. 91, note 125, as attributed to the School of Lodovico Cigoli, but notes that the attribution is by no means certain.  Verso is illustrated at no. 53. (See reference Bib. 40);

From “Dessins baroques…”: exhibition catalogue: under cat. no. 35 as close to Louvre inv. 1069, as identified by Thiem (1977); (See reference Bib. 39);
